column5: Extension
column9: Corpus

column5: Compressed version of BERT using parameter sharing, which is much more efficient given the same number of parameters
column9: Same as BERT

column5: Derived from BART and layernorms located exactly at the beginning of each layer. Encoder initialized with internal 10B pre-trained encoder.
column6: Summarization, multi-lingual machine translation and NLU tasks
column9: Wikipedia and mC4 datasets in 12 languages

column5: Alpaca is fine-tuned from a 7B LLaMA model.
column6: Evaluated on a variety of text generation and classification tasks.
column9: 52K instruction-following data generated using self-instruct mechanism, from 175  human-written instruction-output pairs.

column5: The original Alphafold used a BERT-style transformer. The details of Alphafold’s Transformer are not known, but it is believed it is an extension of the SE(3)-Tranformer, a 3-D equivariant Transformer (see this blog post).
column9: 170,000 proteins from a public repository of protein sequences and structures

column5: These models do not introduce novelties at the architecture/pretraining level and they are based on GPT-3 but rather focuses on how to improve alignment through fine-tuning and prompting. Note that the Anthropic Assistant includes several models optimized for different tasks. Latest versions of this work focus on the benefits of RLHF.
column6: Different models with different applications from general dialog to code assistant.
column9: 400B tokens from filtered Common Crawl and Books. They also create several Dialogue Preference datasets for the RLHF training.

column2: BERT for encoder, GPT for Decoder
column5: It can be seen as a generalization of BERT and GPT in that it combines ideas from both in the encoder and decoder
column6: Mostly text generation but also some text understanding tasks
column9:
Same as RoBERTa (160Gb of news, books, stories,
and web text)

column6: General Language Understanding and Question Answering. Many other language applications followed
column9: Toronto Book Corpus and Wikipedia (3.3B Tokens)

column3: Encoder AND Encoder/Decoder (BigBird is mostly a way to implement sparse attention that is implemented both in an Encoder-only as wells as Encoder/Decoder architecture)
column5: Big Bird can extend other architectures such as BERT, Pegasus, or RoBERTa by using a sparse attention mechanism that elminates the quadratic dependency thus making it more suitable for longer sequences
column6: Particularly well suited for longer sequences, not only in text but also e.g. in genomics
column9: Books, CC-News, Stories and Wikipedia

column5: BlenderBot 3 is based on a pre-trained OPT. It adds features needed for a dialog agent such as long-term memory or the ability to search the internet. It is also fine-tuned for some specific tasks given human feedback on them.
column9: 180B tokens = RoBERTa + the Pile + PushShift.io Reddit

column5: Main difference to GPT-3 is that it uses full attention instead of sparse attention
column9: 366B tokens (1.5 TB of text data) multilingual dataset

column5: ChatGPT takes a GPT3.5 (aka GPT3 Davinci-003) pretrained model and uses RLHF to finetune the model mostly like described in InstructGPT but with slight differences in the data collection. ChatGPT is also more than a model since it includes extensions for Memory Store and retrieval similar to BlenderBot3
column9: Same as GPT3 + datasets generated for RLHF

column5: Same as Gopher but with optimizations to reduce model size and therefore training/inference time with equal or superior performance
column9: Massive Text (2.35 billion documents, or about 10.5 TB of text including Massive Web, Books, Github, News, C4, and Wikipedia.

column2: CLIP (Also using Resnet, ViT, and vanilla transformer for text)
column4:
predict which of the N × N possible (image, text) pairings
across a batch actually occurred
column5: Combines Resnet and ViT for the visual encoding with Transformer for the Textual encoder
column9: WIT (WebImageText) - 400 million text,image pairs

column5: This is somewhat similar to HTML in its use of structured training data. However, it is a different architecture and uses causal masking
column6: Multimodal language model with the ability to do structured prompting
column9: CC-News, English Wikipedia

column5:
model can generate text conditioned on control codes that specify domain, style,
topics, dates, entities, relationships between entities, plot points, and task-related behavior
column9:
140 GB of text including: Wikipedia (En, De, Es, Fr), Project Gutenberg, 45 subreddits, OpenWebText2, Amazon
Reviews, Europarl and UN data from WMT, question-answer pairs from ELI5, and the
MRQA shared task3, which includes the Stanford Question Answering Dataset, NewsQA, TriviaQA, SearchQA, HotpotQA , and Natural Questions

column5: A differential variational auto-encoder is used to learn the visual codebook. The transformer is a variation of GPT-3
column9: 250 million text-images pairs from the internet

column5: Combines CLIP encoder and Diffusion decoder similar to GLIDE
column9: Combination of the DALL-E and CLIP datasets

column5: Separate positional embedding vector independent from the content embedding using disentangled attention matrices for contents and relative positions
column9: English Wikipedia, BookCorpus, OPENWEBTEXT and STORIES

column2: GPT, Control Transformers” (not per se a family, but grouping here those transformers that try to model more general control, RL-like, tasks)
column5: Decision transformers use a GPT architecture and extend it by encoding trajectories in a way that they can be learned by an auto-regressive task
column9: Different corpus for different experiments

column5: GPT-2 architecture trained on dialog data
column9: 140M Reddit conversations

column5: Compressed version of BERT using distillation, which is much more efficient given the same number of parameters
column9: Same as BERT

column5: Adds quantization and distillation to a BART model to improve performance and model size
column8: Up to 30x reduction in parameters compared to standard BART
column9: CNN/DM, XSUM, ELI5, WMT16 En-Ro (~1M tokens)

column4: Fine tuned on Q&A pairs to follow human instructions
column5: fine-tuned based on the GPT-J-6B (V1) and Pythia model (V2)
column9: V1: Instruction corpus same as Alpaca, V2: databricks own dataset.

column4: Fine tuned on Semantic similarity using contrastive loss
column5: Fine-tunes BERT-based models to create text string embeddings optimized for semantic relatedness.
column6: Text embeddings for semantic relatedness tasks such as text clustering or search retrieval.
column9: MS-MARCO, NQ, NLI
Same as BERT except for Large with is same as XLNet

column5: Uses BERT for Encoder architecture, but stacks and aggregates two of them for text and entities. This architecture could be understood as BERT for text + knowledge graphs

column4: Log likelihood of text given some visual input
column5: It uses a frozen textual language model (like Chinchilla) conditioned on the visual representation, which is encoded from a Normalizer-Free ResNet
column9: MultiModal MassiveWeb (M3W): 185 million images and 182 GB text + a number of text paired with image datasets: ALIGN + LTIP (Long Text & Image Pairs) = 312 million images, and VTP (Video & Text Pairs) = 27 million short videos (approximately 22 seconds on average)

column4: Fine tuned on Instructions for zero-shot and few-shot tasks
column5: Flan-T5 is generated by "Flan Finetuning" the T5 models: (1) scaling the number of tasks to 1,836, (2) scaling the model size, and (3) finetuning on chain-of-thought data.
column6: The primary use is to underestand how to improve large language models with the right kind of instruction fine-tuning. The focus is research on zero-shot and in-context few-shot learning NLP tasks, such as reasoning, and question answering; advancing fairness and safety research, and understanding limitations of current large language models
column9: Flan finetuned with tasks in Muffin, T0-SF, NIV2, and CoT.

column4: Fine tuned on Instructions for zero-shot and few-shot tasks
column5: Flan-PaLM is generated by "Flan Finetuning" the PaLM models: (1) scaling the number of tasks to 1,836, (2) scaling the model size, and (3) finetuning on chain-of-thought data.
column6: Same as Flan-T5. The goal is to show Flan finetuning can even improve on the largest Google LMs (+9.4\% improvement average across tasks), with improvements to chain of thought, self consistency, multilingual tasks, arithmetic reasoning
column9: Flan finetuned with tasks in Muffin, T0-SF, NIV2, and CoT.

column5: Transformer based architecture in a decoder-only setup with a few modifications. Data extensions include special tokens for working memory, citations, genetic data, and a few other biology related tasks.
column6: he models are designed to perform scientific tasks, including but not limited to citation prediction, scientific QA, mathematical reasoning, summarization, document generation, molecular property prediction and entity extraction.
column9: Trained on 106 billion tokens of open-access scientific text and data. This includes papers, textbooks, scientific websites, encyclopedias, reference material, knowledge bases, and more

column2: “Control Transformers” (not per se a family, but grouping here those transformers that try to model more general control, RL-like, tasks)
column4: MLM (where tokens are either text or agent actions)
column5: The standard decoder-only transformer architecture is preceded by an embedding layer that can embed text and images, plus add position encodings to add spatial information when applicable.
column6: Gato presents a generalizable agent that can be used beyond text to tasks such as playing Atari or controlling a robot arm.
column9: 1.5T tokens including standard text (e.g. MassiveText), vision (e.g. ALIGN), and simulation environments (e.g. ALE Atari, or RGB Stacking Real Robot)

column5: GLaM introduces a Mixture of 64 Experts to increase parameter count and generalization properties in a somewhat standard decoder-only. Transformer architecture. Only two experts get activated at a time per token, which makes the model also more efficient in training and inference.
column8: 1.2T across 64 experts, but only 96B get activated for inference
column9: 1.6T tokens including web pages filtered by Wikipedia and books for quality

column5: GLIDE can be seen as an extension of the ADM (Ablated Diffusion Model) by the same authors. However, ADM is not per se a transformer architecture although it does resemble one in some of the configurations the authors use. Given that ADM is by the same authors and was quickly followed up by GLIDE, I think it is fair to consider GLIDE as the first of its kind.
column8: 3.5B diffusion model (2.3B for visual encoding, 1.2B for textual) + 1.5B for model for upsampling
column9: Same as DALL-E

column5: GLM has a bidirectional encoder and a unidirectional decoder in a unified model.
column6: General Language Model pretrained with an autoregressive blank-filling objective and can be finetuned on various natural language understanding and generation tasks.
column9: Pile, GLM-130B Chinese corpora, P3, DeepStruct finetuning dataset

column5: hierarchical ViT architecture consisting of local and global self-attention modules
column9: Imagenet-1K and other task dependent dataasets

column5: Same as GPT-2 but use RSNorm instead of LayerNorm and relative positional encoding rather than absolute
column6: Mostly Language Modeling and NLU, but also extensible like GPT
column9: Massive Text (2.35 billion documents, or about 10.5 TB of text including Massive Web, Books, Github, News, C4, and Wikipedia.

column5: GopherCite is based on Gopher but adds a step using RLHP (Reinforcement Learning from Human Preferences) to learn whether not only a response is plausible but also supported
column6: Dialog systems, Q&A, general language generation tasks
column9: Same as Gopher plus specific dataset generated in the RLHP process

column6: Text generation, but adaptable to many other NLP tasks when fine tuned.
column9: Unsupervised Pretraining on BookCorpus dataset. Supervised Finetuning on several task-specific datasets including SNLI, RACE, Quora...

column5: Minor extensions to the GPT architecture (e.g. layer normalization moved to the input of each sub-layer, or increased context size from 512 to 1024)
column6: Text generation, but adaptable to many other NLP tasks when fine tuned.
column9: 8 million web pages (40 GB). 10X GPT . WebText dataset is created by crawling all links at Reddit with at least 3 Karma points.

column5:
Same as GPT-2 with the only addition of alternating dense and locally banded sparse
attention patterns, inspired by the Sparse Transformer
column6: Initially text generation, but has over time been used for a large range of applications in areas such as code generation, but also image and audio generation
column9: ~ 500B tokens including CommonCrawl (410B), WebText2 (19B), Books1 (12B), Books2 (55B), and Wikipedia (3B)

column5: The GPT3.5 series includes a number of models like Davinci-003. They are basically versions of the InstructGPT model. See here for details on the comparison of the performance to older GPT3 models.
column6: Dialog and general language, but there is a code specific model too
column9: Same as InstructGPT

column5: GPT-J 6B is a Transformer model trained using Mesh Transformer JAX and same tokenizer as GPT2/3
column9: Pile corpus, a large-scale curated dataset created by EleutherAI.

column5: Similar to GPT-2 but uses local attention in every other layer with a window size of 256 tokens
column6: Text generation, but adaptable to many other NLP tasks when fine tuned.
column9: Pile - 840 GB open source text dataset that combines 22 pre existing datasets

column5: Similar to GPT-3 with rotary encoders instead of positional, parallel attention and feed forward layers, different initialization, and all dense layers instead of alternate dense/sparse
column9: Pile (22 data sources)

column5: GPTInstruct starts off with a pretrained GPT3 model and adds reward modeling through reinforcement learning after a supervised finetuning
column9: Same as GPT3 for pretraining, but finetuned and optimized using labeler data and prompts

column4: Fine tuned with a wide variety of instruction based text-to-text tasks
column5: Fine-tunes T5 explicitly to optimize encoder to produce a general purpose text string embedding useful for many NLU tasks.
column6: Any NLU task requiring a single text string embedding. As of April 2023 InstructOR is the top-ranked system on the Massive Text Embedding Benchmark (MTEB)
column9: Finetuned on MEDI
column11: University of Hong Kong, University of Washington, META AI

column5: As opposed to BART, they don’t do sentence shuffling
column6: General purpose language model that allows structured HTML prompting
column9: 23TB of simplified HTML extracted from CommonCrawl

column3: T5 (or CLIP or BERT) for frozen text encoder + U-net architecture for cascaded diffusion models for text to image
column5: Imagen adds a few extensions to the U-net diffusion architecture (pooled embedding vector, cross attention over text embeddings, and Layer Normalizations)
column9: a combination of internal datasets, with ≈ 460M image-text pairs, and the publicly available Laion dataset, with ≈ 400M image-text pairs

column5: Very similar to GPT-3, but far more parameters and improved training efficiency mostly because of the improved tokenizer. Also, different ratio of depth to breadth
column9: 300B tokens (same as GPT-3)

column5: LAMDA focuses on how to improve safety, quality, and groundeness using different fine-tuning strategies
column9: 1.56T words from public dialog data and other public web documents

column5: LLaMA uses a Transformer architecture, and with extensions: Pre-normalization, SwiGLU activations, RoPE embeddings,  reduced memory usage and runtime through efficient implementation of the causal multi-head attention, checkpointing to reduce the amount of activations that are recomputed during the backward pass, model and sequence parallelism to reduce memory usage of the model, and uses 1.4T BPE tokens after tokenization.
column6: Zero and few shot Commonsense reasoning, Question answering, Code generation and Reading comprehension.
column9: English CommonCrawl + C4 + Github + Wikipedia + Gutenberg and Books3 + ArXiv + Stack Exchange
CC25 Corpus includes 25 monolingual corpuses in different languages. Largest corpuses are English (300 GB) and Russian (280GB)

column3: Encoder or Decorder, depending on the base model
column5: Megatron is a family of models that extend previously known architectures (namely GPT-2 and BERT originally, but also T5 more recently) by introducing model parallelism primitives. In the case of BERT, the authors also replace the next sentence prediction head with sentence order prediction and use whole word n-gram masking.
column9: Original paper uses an aggregate dataset consisting of Wikipedia), CC-Stories), RealNews, and OpenWebtext

column5: Extends PaLM by fine-tuning on the mathematical dataset
column9: Same as PaLM + ​​118GB dataset of scientific papers from the arXiv preprint server and web pages that contain mathematical expressions using LaTeX, MathJax, or other mathematical typesetting formats

column5: Uses parallelization similar to Megatron to train a LM double the size of GPT-3
column6: Language generation and others (similar to GPT-3)
column9: The Pile (800GB dataset) + 2 Common Crawl snapshots

column5: Supervised fine-tuning on crowd sourced conversation/assistant data.
column6: Same as ChatGPT, but open source. Compared to alternatives, it uses human generated conversation data
column9: Conversations collected by volunteers, available at https://huggingface.co/datasets/OpenAssistant/oasst1
column10: Limited, Non-commercial bespoke license. There is also a version based on Pythia which is Apache licensed.

column5: Basically same architecture as GPT-3 but with some training improvements introduced in Megatron-LM
column9: 180B tokens = RoBERTa + the Pile + PushShift.io Reddit

column5: Palm uses a typical decoder-only transformer architecture, but adds quite a few extensions: SwiGLU activations, parallel layers, multi-query attention, RoPE embeddings, Shared Input-Output Embeddings, no biases, and a 256k SentencePiece vocabulary generated from the training data
column9: 780B tokens from filtered webpages, books, Wikipedia, news articles, source code, and social media conversations. Code includes 24 programming languages.

column5: Extends vanilla Transformer by using a different pretraining task (GSG: Gap Sentence Generation) that is better suited for summarization
column9: C4 (750GB) + HugeNews (3.8 TB)

column5: Extension of BERT with optimized training procedure and more data
column9: Same as BERT + CC News + OpenWebText + Stories (~33B Tokens)

column3: Encoder/decoder or decoder only, depending on the base model it’s extending
column4: Encoder/decoder or decoder only, depending on the base model it’s extending
column5: SeeKer is an extension that can be applied to any Transformer architecture by introducing “search”, “knowledge”, and “response” modules that are introduced during pretraining
column9: Same as base model

column5: Starts from the Chinchilla 70B model but adds RLHF (Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback). It also adds inline evidence a la GopherCite
column6: Dialog agents and general language generation applications like Q&A
column9: Same as Chinchilla + interactive data gathering with human annotators during the RLHF process

column5: Stable diffusion is basically the Latent Diffusion model developed by LMU Munich researchers + some learnings on conditional diffusion from DALL-e and Imagen
column9: LAION-5B, a publicly available dataset derived from Common Crawl

column5: Extends ViT by replacing the standard multi-head self attention (MSA) module by a module based on shifted windows (Swin) allowing ViT-like architectures to generalize to higher resolution images
column9: Imagenet and Imagenet-22k

column5: Goal to increase parameter count while keeping FLOP operations constant by using efficient routing of MoE (Mixture of Experts)
column9: Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus

column4: Fine tuned with Natural language prompts
column5: T0 stands for "T5 for Zero Shot", obtained by fine-tuning the T5 model on multitask mixture covering many different NLP tasks. Compared with T0, T0p and T0pp were fine-tuned with more datasets. T0pp is recommended as it leads (on average) to the best performances on a variety of NLP tasks.
column6: Perform zero-shot inference tasks by specifying the query in natural language, and the models will generate a prediction.
column9: T0 (Multiple-choice QA, Extractive QA, Closed-Book QA, Structure-To-Text, Sentiment, Summarization, Topic Classification, Paraphrase Identification. T0p (same as T0, with additional datasets from GPT-3's evaluation suite). T0pp (same as T0p, with additional datasets from SuperGLUE, excluding NLI sets)

column5: Same as original Transformer with some additions such as relative positional embeddings like Transformer XL
column6:
General language tasks including machine translation,
question answering, abstractive summarization, and text classification
column9: Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus (C4) - Cleaned up version of the Common Crawl dataset - 750 GB

column2: GPT, Control Transformers” (not per se a family, but grouping here those transformers that try to model more general control, RL-like, tasks)
column5: Similarly to the Decision transformers, the main extension introduced by Trajectory Transformers is a way to encode a trajectory (state, actions, rewards)
column9: D4RL dataset and other RL datasets depending on the task at hand

column5: Relative positioned embeddings enable longer-context attention when compared to vanilla Transformer model
column9: Different training datasets depending on experiments, but baseline is Wikitext-103

column5: Optimized version of GPT2 with optimal hyperparameters and software/hardware platform to improve training
column9: Highest quality subset from The Pile + 2 CC snapshots (339B tokens)

column4: Mixture-of-Denoisers, which combines diverse pre-training paradigms together
column5: UL2-20B (Unifying Language Learning) can be interpreted as a model that is quite similar to T5 but trained with a different objective and slightly different scaling knobs.
column6: A unified framework for pre-training models that are universally effective across datasets and setups.

column9: Conversations collected from ShareGPT

column5: Extension of BERT architecture to train on patches of images
column9: From standard Imagenet to JFT-300M (large inhouse dataset)

column5: An extension of RoBERTa that introduces small parameter tuning insights in the context of multilingual applications

column9: Cleaned Common Crawl in 100 languages

column9:
Same as BERT + Giga5 (16GB text),
